cards.desc:
From PP mentor:

> Standard indexes (with just a few levels of indentation) are quite easy to handle, even in the HTML version; provided that the formatters did their job thoroughly for the text version. Just go back to the the text version, copy the index, and paste it into an empty Guiguts window (you can either close the text file or even open another instance of Guiguts). Now, just highlight the pasted list and run 'HTML Auto Index (List)' from the 'HTML' menu. Guiguts will produce the HTML code within a few seconds, which you can subsequently paste into your HTML version. You just have to check for incorrect links (e.g., numbers which are not page numbers), and you are done. Of course, you can always adjust the appearance of your index by applying a few additional CSS classes. But please, be very careful and don't forget to keep a backup for your original HTML file--just in case
cards.name: Index (TBD)

cards.desc:
Don't even try to do this by yourself, post in the forum, there's a great guy that will just do the Hebrew for you.

If you have Hebrew in the project, make sure to tell PPV (and have them mention to WW) so they know to expect it.

**NOTE** Hebrew will break gutcheck (bookloupe) - may be better to wait until after gutcheck time to insert it, though that will mean doing it twice for the two file versions.

Guiguts will insert Hebrew properly, but will display it backward (LTR instead of RTL).

Visual Studio Code will both insert and display properly.

Atom doesn't work for this - don't use it.
cards.name: Hebrew

cards.desc:
Should be simple, no spaces, lowercase, e.g. "missfairfax" was used for "Miss Fairfax of Virginia".

This is used by scripts, in the github repo, preview site, so use consistently.

cards.desc:
The guidelines for image sizing changed in June 2020.

See [this thread](https://www.pgdp.net/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?f=3&t=70286) for more information.

> I've heard from Greg Newby at Project Gutenberg and he's approved the following size limits:
>
> Covers. Covers should be at least 650x1000 pixels (width x height) and up to 5000x5000 pixels. Larger dimensions are recommended. Cover file size should be no larger than 256K.
>
> Inline images. Normal illustrations should be no larger than 256K and up to 5000x5000 pixels in dimension.
>
> Linked-to images. Images that are targets of an href can be no larger than 1 MB and up to 5000x5000 pixels.
cards.name: UPDATED GUIDELINES

cards.desc:
Make a list of illustrations that need to be handled. They are located in `pngs/`, named e.g. `cover`,`i001`, `illus-001`...

It may help to open two windows to compare the illustrations to verify which ones go in which locations. This assumes the high-quality scans are JPEG files instead of PNG files. They were in `winefred`.

```
cd pngs
open -a Preview *.png
open -a Preview *.jpg
```
cards.name: Locate illustrations

cards.desc:
Put illustrations in `illustrations/` to clean up `pngs/`, but save the final output images to `images` folder.

Longest side no more than 400-600px at most. They should be sized proportional to how much space they took on the printed page. e.g. an illustrated drop cap is probably only 100-125px tall.

Monochrome images, use PNG. Color images use JPEG.

Pay attention to file size. A cover image, I was told, should be closer to 100KB instead of what I submitted, 300KB.

epubmaker recommends covers be 600x800px, cover should be at least 500px wide. Covers should be 50-150KB in size, and *must* be JPEG format. More [here](http://www.pgdp.net/wiki/Easy_Epub/Cover).

JPEG can't do transparency, if you need transparency, add an alpha channel to the source image and export as PNG.

If images need be larger than these guidelines to be readable, so be it. As long as we use max-width in CSS later, they will not clip off the sides of the page. Some in the forums say that the current guidelines are out of date, written in days when browsers and ebook readers were much less capable. To keep them in scale (relative to the page width), you can set the width to a percentage.

JPEG is much more compressible, so a large PNG can probably benefit from being converted to JPEG.

Images with captions don't need an `alt` tag.
cards.name: Process illustrations

cards.desc:
If you modify an image substantially, e.g. removing a library sticker or stamp, add a mention of this in the TN (front matter). Also indicate the new image is placed in the public domain, as discused [here](http://www.pgdp.net/wiki/Easy_Epub/Cover).

This is a PG requirement. The link includes HTML/CSS for adding a front matter TN, if needed.
cards.name: Substantially changing an image

cards.desc:
If no cover was provided, you should fabricate one for the ebook. See [here](http://www.pgdp.net/wiki/Easy_Epub/Cover) for more information.

You will need a front matter TN, and a public domain declaration. This is a PG requirement. Something like "The cover image was created by the transcriber and is placed in the public domain."

The link above has some HTML/CSS that will hide the cover in the HTML version and show it in the ebook version. The HTML version doesn't really need a cover, so if we are at the point of fabricating one, then we only want it to be applied to the ebook.

DP policy is that when fabricating a cover image, we use only images found within the book as provided (not images found in other versions of the book, or images from anywhere else). See more at the above link.

There is a [team thread](http://www.pgdp.net/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?t=57674) of people who are willing to volunteer to create custom covers for projects.
cards.name: Fabricating a cover

cards.desc: If fixing the image is beyond your ability, try asking for help in the [Illustrators thread](http://www.pgdp.net/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?t=17712).
cards.name: Outsourcing image modifications

cards.desc:
Transparent PNG works fine for iBooks and ADE apps. Kindle seems to ignore transparency and uses the background color (or defaults to black if there isn't any background color data present).

If using Gimp, export as PNG, using these options:

- [_] Interlacing (Adam7)
- [X] Save background color
- [_] Save gamma
- [_] Save layer offset
- [X] Save resolution
- [X] Save creation time
- [_] Save comment
- [_] Save color values from transparent pixels

In my testing, this still renders non-transparent in Kindle app (it is on a white background if you switch to another background color), but it's better than before when I had a black blackground on the default white page. Renders transparent/correct in iBooks & ADE.
cards.name: Transparent PNGs

cards.desc:
PG WWers only take one text file. It can be `.txt` (Latin-1) or it can be `-utf8.txt` (UTF-8). I say, UTF-8 always. Just make sure then that it is actually UTF-8 and you found all the Latin-1.

The `make_project.py` script does an auto-conversion at project creation time.
cards.name: UTF8

cards.desc:
A regex to find Latin-1 accented and special characters.

```
[\xa0-\xff]
```

Note that this will also match on UTF-8 encoded Latin characters, so this is not a way to locate ISO-8859-1 encodings, only a way to locate accented characters.
cards.name: To find accented characters

cards.desc: Set up guiguts so it is aware of the book's page numbering. This makes it easy to locate things later, especially after page markers have been removed, and the page numbers also get used in the HTML version.
cards.name: Fix page numbers

cards.desc: Blank pages are meaningless in the electronic version, so we remove them.
cards.name: Remove blank pages

cards.desc:
The front matter (title page, copyright, TOC, and other stuff that comes before the main body of the book) are full of unusual items that require close scrutiny to handle correctly.

Don't leave `/*` above the title, guiguts gets screwed up by that.
cards.name: Front matter

cards.desc:
Not yet written up in Trello. If you get a project with an index, work it out.

[Miller's workflow](http://www.pgdp.net/wiki/User:Miller#Index)

Start during first pass.
cards.name: Index (TBD)

cards.desc: The purpose of this skim is to page through the book looking for all the stuff that's not "just text," and make sure it's looked at. This will hopefully be gone through again as we go, but it's a good idea to hit on the obvious things right at the start too.
cards.name: First-pass skim

cards.desc: Remove the page separators from the text. Guiguts still knows where the page boundaries were.
cards.name: Remove page separators

cards.desc: Check each proofer's note and handle as appropriate.
cards.name: Proofer's notes

cards.desc:
This book has its own errata.

See https://www.pgdp.net/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?f=3&t=15019&start=21930#p1231519
cards.name: Apply book's errata

cards.desc: Find hyphenated words and handle appropriately.
cards.name: Hyphenated words in question

cards.desc: Convert the thought breaks.
cards.name: Thought breaks

cards.desc: Look for orphaned markup (unmatched brackets / tags).
cards.name: Orphaned markup

cards.desc: This takes forever. Check every `he` and `be`. On my first project, even doing this, I still missed one that I found later.
cards.name: Jeebies

cards.desc:
Look at various odd cases.

When looking in `Hyphens`, note that for Google Ngram, you must put spaces around the hyphen in a hyphenated word, `foo - bar` not `foo-bar`. Otherwise it is interpreted as `foo but not bar`.
cards.name: Word Frequency

cards.desc:
If book uses Mr., Mrs., and so on, might want to check for those with a space after (e.g. search for missing periods).

- Mr.
- Mrs.
- Dr.
- Mme.
- Mlle.
- Messrs.
- St.
cards.name: Titles missing periods

cards.desc:
This is a swiss army knife tool, looks for a lot of different stuff.

In each section, `Search` until there's no more matches, then `Next Stealtho` to go to the next thing in the list. Each `.rc` file has multiple things it looks for.
cards.name: Stealth Scannos
Check for other A. M., P. M.

cards.desc: Careful spell check. Use the old dictionaries and Ngrams if needed.
cards.name: Spellcheck

cards.desc: There's one instance of Chatta**c**hoochie. (extra _c_)
cards.name: Fix Chattahoochie

cards.desc: Only one of these, should be Allatoona with two Ls.
cards.name: Fix Alatoona

cards.desc: Bookloupe is just a guide, it is not always right.
cards.name: Bookloupe 1

cards.desc: Look over notes to see what else should be done before HTML split (to avoid headaches later after there are two versions already).
cards.name: Check notes for pre-HTML-split work

cards.desc: Save a copy for HTML before we do some "text only" things to the text version.
cards.name: Save a copy for HTML

cards.desc:
Superscripts are denoted with `^`, examples:

```
M^cCaskill
The 9^{th} regiment
```

It is up to PP to determine how to handle these. For instance you can simply turn `9^{th}` into `9th` or you can leave it that way and add a TN describing what you've done.

Just be consistent so that the reader knows what it means.
cards.name: Superscripts

cards.desc:
Add the transcriber's notes that you've been keeping. I use the original book's page numbers for some reason, it's better than using the image numbers I guess, even though in the text version there are no page numbers.

Include a bit of text for change entries, so the reader can find the place you changed.

`p. 123: changed "foo" to "fool" (the fool and his money)`

Usually a generic text header is also appropriate, like:

> Some punctuation has been standardized. Some alternate spellings may have been retained. Some obvious misspellings and typographical errors/omissions have been corrected. Any other changes are noted below.
cards.name: Add TN

cards.desc:
Change the various DP markup tags to something more appropriate for text.

Note in case of bold:

```
Transcriber's Note: Italic text is denoted by
_underscores_ and bold text by =equal signs=.
```
cards.name: Convert Tags

cards.desc:
I tidy up the table of contents before rewrapping. Align the numbers and chapter headers so that it looks nice and clean. Rewrapping will add about 8 spaces before each line. If that will make your lines too long, (i.e. longer than say 72), you may want to do this by hand. Line everything up the way you want it to be, then highlight the table of contents by clicking and dragging over the whole thing. Then go to Selection->Indent selection 1. Twice. That will indent the whole selection 2 spaces. PG asks that things that are indented be so at least two spaces. You can do it more if you like, just watch that right margin. If you place your cursor after a number in the table of contents, the first box on the bottom of the GG window will tell you how far to the right you are. Mine ends as Col. 65, so I am set. Now, if you have indented your TOC yourself, immediately change the `/*` and `*/` surrounding it to `/$ $/`. This tells GG to just ignore that bit when rewrapping.

Another option is to put a number in brackets right after the opening `/*[2]`. This will tell GG that for this section, you want a two space indentation instead of your usual eight spaces, (or whatever you've got your preferences set to).
cards.name: Table of Contents

cards.desc:
[Miller's workflow](http://www.pgdp.net/wiki/User:Miller#Text_Version_Footnotes)

Must be done before rewrapping the text.
cards.name: Footnotes

cards.desc: Rewrap the book text. Now that we've removed all the proofer notes and rejoined hyphenated words, things are out of joint. Rewrap will fix it for you.
cards.name: Rewrap

cards.desc: Just another bookloupe check, after doing various things since last one. Reminder, bookloupe is not always right, it is only a guide.
cards.name: Bookloupe 2

cards.desc:
**DO THIS AFTER GUTCHECK!** So you will probably have to do it for text and HTML files separately.

[Miller's workflow](http://www.pgdp.net/wiki/User:Miller#Greek)

Post in the [forum](https://www.pgdp.net/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?t=15744) asking for help. Include the text to transcribe (as it appears in the proofer output) and links to the PNGs and/or high-quality scans.

Then when someone responds, simply copy/paste their output into the text file. Then remove the `[Greek: ...]` tag entirely, the new text replaces it.

Use `<i>` tags if the text is italic, as normal.

This only works for UTF-8 so if for some reason you aren't doing a UTF-8 version, then skip this and leave the transliterated latin text instead.
cards.name: Greek

cards.desc:
This **must** be done AFTER gutcheck. Gutcheck cannot handle some UTF-8 characters and will just blow up.

We have already broken from HTML, so we probably need to make the same changes in both text and HTML files.
cards.name: Look for brackets, fix up stuff like macron chars

cards.desc:
First line of the file has a UTF-8 hack. Time to remove it.

(NOTE: first time we do this on a final project, see if it actually goes back to latin-1. If there is a single em-dash it probably will be ok.)

I believe guiguts will return to Latin-1 encoding if there is no utf-8 stuff in the file.
cards.name: Remove UTF-8 hack

cards.desc:
Ads with a price listing along the right or other special formatting... remember to indent by at least 1 space, to avoid rewrapping.

Further advice from PPV mentor:

> When you do 'pptxt' in Guiguts, any items in the 'adjacent spaces check' category should always be checked one more time. Passages with a correct 'no-rewrap' (indented passages) will never be listed in pptxt.
cards.name: Advertisements

cards.desc: Open our HTML file in guiguts
cards.name: Open file

cards.desc:
Sometimes there will be a "PAGE" designation on the right above the number. remove the spaces before it to make it land on the left margin. Now here is where I do something wacky that helps me later. I type "Blah" right before "PAGE" and then add some spaces after it. So:

`PAGE`

now looks like

`Blah            Page`

This will help me in making the table shortly. "Blah" is my space holder and will be replaced with ` ` when I actually make the table. Putting ` ` in right now would be a Bad Idea as GG will convert the `&` into code. Before finishing the file completely, I can run a check for "Blah" and make sure none got left behind. Make sure that each page number is spaced at least 2 spaces from the title. DP requires six but GG only needs two.
cards.name: Table of Contents 1

cards.desc:
[Miller's workflow](http://www.pgdp.net/wiki/User:Miller#Footnotes_for_HTML)

Must be done before generating the HTML.
cards.name: Footnotes

cards.desc: Automatically generate the HTML from the text version. Sometimes, GG puts the closing `` one footnote too early. Check your second to the last footnote. If it has ``, move one of them so that your LAST footnote ends ``.
cards.name: Generate HTML

cards.desc:
My CSS sets up indentation of the first line of each paragraph, as is common in books. Use `

` for any paragraph requiring zero indentation, for example a continuation paragraph where an illustration is placed within the paragraph.
cards.name: Paragraph indentation

cards.desc:
Not written up in Trello yet. If you get an Index project, work it out.

[Miller's workflow](http://www.pgdp.net/wiki/User:Miller#Index)

Do after auto-generating the HTML.
cards.name: Index (TBD)

cards.desc: The markers default to `[Pg_n]`, change them to `[n]`.
cards.name: Clean up page number markers

cards.desc:
We will be doing our own TOC later instead of using this.

TOC starts and ends with HTML comments like:

```
<!-- Autogenerated TOC. Modify or delete as required. -->
```
cards.name: Remove auto-generated TOC

cards.desc:
If any vertical space is needed, don't do a lame hack like ```

 

``` Use CSS and a div. ```
``` I used to use something like `
` but did not work, some inheritance was broken. Using a clean, single class works better.
cards.name: Adding vertical space

cards.desc: Don't use ` ` just to insert space, e.g. like this: ```   ``` It might work but it will create diff issues in pptools. Instead use the unicode zero-width space: ``` ​ ``` And there is a checkbox to ignore those, so they won't show up in diffs in pptools.
cards.name: Inserting horizontal space

cards.desc:
Right-align an attribution, but offset from right margin a bit. Can be used inside a blockquote, or outside. ```

{{ the quote }}

{{ author }}

{{ author }}

```
cards.name: Blockquotes & attributions

cards.desc:
Make it look nice. Probably most of it should be centered. Only use `

` for headers, not for presentation. Breaks things. Can format subhead and byline with CSS if desired. Use `
` instead of `

` for this, as `

` is probably doing auto-indentation. ```

A ROMANCE OF LOVE AND ADVENTURE UNDER THE PALMETTOS
BY ST. GEORGE RATHBORNE
``` The copyright notices which were in fixed-format blocks before may have this: `` If they are put into a centered div instead, no point in keeping those.
cards.name: Format title page
Table of Contents 2

cards.desc: If the book has a list of illustrations, treat it like a TOC. Copy that card and process it the same way, except for the checklist items here.
cards.name: List of Illustrations

cards.desc: Center the chapter beginning in each chapter.
cards.name: Chapter centering

cards.desc:
If this book uses drop caps, add those. If it uses _illustrated_ drop caps, there's more to it. ([Reference](http://www.pgdp.net/wiki/DP_Official_Documentation:PP_and_PPV/Easy_Epub/Dropcaps)) ```

One grey, ``` If a book has the drop cap text printed all in one case, but it contains a capital letter such as a name, _preserve the capital_ even though it will look different. Some epub formatters, including ADE, cannot do small caps, so then you will end up with an improper case.
cards.name: Drop caps
Illustrated drop caps

cards.desc:
Add the illustrations to the book. Simple illustration: ```
``` With alt & title attributes: ```
``` With a caption and anchor: ```
SUDDENLY HOLWOOD STOOPED AND PRESSED HIS LIPS TO HER BROW.
```
cards.name: Place illustrations

cards.desc:
[Miller's workflow](http://www.pgdp.net/wiki/User:Miller#Greek)

You already did the transcription part in the text version so that is done. You probably don't need to do anything else except ensure the HTML file has

```html
<meta charset="UTF-8">
```

in the `<head>` section.

Miller's workflow mentions using HTML entities, but that is probably not necessary in modern browsers? Perhaps in lower-quality ebook readers, but if they are that low-end, it's as likely as not they can't display Greek characters anyway?
cards.name: Greek

cards.desc:
Superscripts are denoted with `^`, examples:

```
M^cCaskill
The 9^{th} regiment
```

Use the `<sup>` element to turn these into proper superscripts in HTML.
cards.name: Superscripts

cards.desc:
Include the TN at the end of the file (just like the text version). (Can I now use the new .transnote class?) TN boilerplate: ```

Transcriber's Notes

Some punctuation has been standardized. Some alternate spellings may have been retained. Some obvious misspellings and typographical errors/omissions have been corrected. Any other changes are noted below.

```
cards.name: Transcriber's notes

cards.desc: Move punctuation inside italic tags if needed. Change ligatures to HTML entities. (Note: what about ae ligature? There is also `&aelig, &AElig`).
cards.name: Italic / ligature fixup

cards.desc: Each italic tag is categorized semantically. Categories: * ` ` is used when a word is italic for emphasis in the text. * ` ` is used when a reference is cited. The New York Times, Washington Irving, etc. * ` ` is used to indicate a language other than the original's in the text. ("Bonjour, m'ami!" he shouted.) * If none of these fit, just leave as ` `
cards.name: Italic semantic fixup

cards.desc: If your book uses small-caps A.D., B.C., A.M., P.M., and so on, fix for HTML.
cards.name: A.D., B.C., et al.

cards.desc:
I am confused where these anchors came from, because they were deleted earlier? but I can't find now where they were restored. Update, this may not be relevant; I skipped this for Winefred. The TOC will be linked using `Page_nn` anchors, so this may only be a thing I used for Miss Fairfax, where I fabricated the chapter links. So just use the page number anchors instead on future projects. Guiguts anchors aren't what we want, need to fix them. It generates: ```

Miss Fairfax

CHAPTER I. ``` But we want the text label outside the `` tag: ```

Miss Fairfax

CHAPTER I. ``` It also doesn't include `id` attributes for many of them. Add those.
cards.name: Fix title anchors

cards.desc:
If there is an ending like "THE END." at the end, center & bold it. ```

THE END

```
cards.name: "The End"

cards.desc:
See [Formatting Chapter Headings to Avoid unwanted page breaks mid-chapter](http://www.pgdp.net/wiki/DP_Official_Documentation:PP_and_PPV/Easy_Epub/Headings#Formatting_Chapter_Headings_to_Avoid_unwanted_page_breaks_mid-chapter). So, basically, all we have to do is to add `
` or `
` where we want to make sure there is a page break, and add to the CSS `div.chapter` and/or `div.section` with `{page-break-before: always;}` It seems that the below regex can be overly greedy on the first match (title page, etc). To fix that, I have before manually added a chapter div between the `
` and the `Page_1` anchor, and then the regex proceeded like it ought to. (Also add `class="nobreak"` to that first `h2` that was missed in the greedy match.) To add the div, use a regex search: ``` \n(
)\n+(

(.+?)

)\n+

``` Replace with: ``` \n$1\n\n
\n\n$2\n\n

``` There are other methods that some use successfully, but the PPV guidelines ask that we use the chapter div method. And in any other places where there should be page breaks, add the div by hand. For instance, in _Miss Fairfax of Virginia_, I added one by hand around the copyright notice, which was on its own page in the original printing.
cards.name: epub-friendly chapter dividers

cards.desc:
First line of the file has a UTF-8 hack. Time to remove it.

(NOTE: first time we do this on a final project, see if it actually goes back to latin-1. If there is a single em-dash it probably will be ok.)
cards.name: Remove UTF-8 hack

cards.desc:
Get rid of extra blank lines in HTML source.

- Search: `\n\n\n`
- Replace: `\n\n`

Regex, start at beginning.
cards.name: Clean up extra blank lines

cards.desc:
There is a good [case study](http://www.pgdp.org/~jana/best-practices/pages/case-studies/poetry/) on this topic, but here are the highlights. A poem is made up of stanzas. A stanza is made up of lines. A line may be indented. Normally stanzas are separated by a blank line. A poem may consist of only one stanza. Basic structure: ```
First line
Second line
Third line
Fourth line
``` To indent a line a bit, add `indent2` class. To indent further, use `indent0` class instead. To center the entire poem on the page, wrap the above in `
..
`. In the ebook version, it will not be centered, instead it will be indented by `1.5em`. This is because many ebook readers don't grok the centering method, and are usually on smaller screens anyway.
cards.name: Format poetry / songs, etc

cards.desc:
Self-closing tags should have a space before the `/`. This can be found with a regex.

    ([^\s])(/>)

Replace with: `$1 $2`.
cards.name: Check self-closing tags

cards.desc: Not going to write this all up for now, but I did one of these in Winefred, can look there for some ideas.
cards.name: Advertisements

cards.desc:
1. Don't use `!important` in CSS, this seems to break ADE. It seems it can't parse the CSS, so all CSS is ignored.

2. ADE does not recognize smallcaps.

3. Kindle (at least for Mac) seems to render transparent PNG backgrounds as black.

4. On [page breaks in iBooks](http://www.pigsgourdsandwikis.com/2011/11/keeping-it-together-page-breaks-in.html).

5. Kindle (at least on Mac) does not seem to honor `page-break-*` CSS. EPUB seems to, or at least iBooks and ADE on Mac do.

6. If you build ebooks and do not have a cover yet, the first illustration is assumed to be the cover. This may render things like illustrations or title page publisher stamps invisible.
cards.name: Ebook notes

cards.desc:
https://www.pgdp.net/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?f=3&t=15019&p=1102349#p1102349

> Kindle screwup; it does not respect attribute: `width` on a div. But setting all of `min-width`, `width`, and `max-width` explicitly fixes the problem. I suspect that Kindle probably sets `min-width` to `100%`, and my setting it over-rides the kindle spec.

---

> Kindle ignores `max-width`, as Richard said.
>
> If you want your narrow text to be centered (column-centered with smooth margins), add `margin: auto;` to the "narrow" definition. Otherwise, it'll be left-positioned along the body's main left margin.
cards.name: Kindle and narrow columns

cards.desc:
To side-load via USB, add the file to `Documents/`, **not** `Books/`.
It will show up in the Docs section on the device, not under Books.

When ejecting, first eject the device on Mac, and then tap "Disconnect" on the device, and then pull the USB cable.
cards.name: Kindle Fire notes

cards.desc: Build `.epub` and `.mobi` books and make sure they look OK.
cards.name: Review ebooks

cards.desc:
The TOC generated by the ebook makers should have proper book structure. If not, then something is wrong. There should only be one `

` used, and `

` should only be used for things that should be in the TOC. If there are things that don't belong there, than change them to `

` with a class of `booktitle`, `subhead`, `byline`, or similar as the case warrants.
cards.name: Review ebook TOC
Tables need more padding... the tables without borders, anyway.

cards.desc: After all the processing we have done, we need to verify we didn't _introduce_ orphaned markup ourselves.
cards.name: Orphaned markup

cards.desc: This checks to be sure that everything that links in your project, like the TOC goes somewhere, and isn't broken. It also checks to be sure that you've used all of the illustrations in your "images" file.
cards.name: Link Checker

cards.desc: Use HTML Tidy to validate your HTML.
cards.name: Tidy

cards.desc:
Upload the file to PG's W3C validator site.

Sometimes it will give you hundreds of errors, but this is really caused by a small error that cascades through the document screwing up everything that comes after it.
cards.name: PG Markup Validator
Check PPTools

cards.desc: Open board menu, filter cards (shortcut: `w f`), filter on `Pending`.
cards.name: Look for pending items

cards.desc:
https://www.pgdp.net/ppwb/

https://www.pgdp.net/wiki/DP_Official_Documentation:PP_and_PPV/Post-Processing_Workbench
cards.name: PP Workbench

cards.desc:
Once fairly confident you are done, submit to SR for two weeks (at least, assuming the book isn't relatively long).

```
You can find other formats (HTML, EPUB, Kindle) and post-processor notes for this project here:

https://dp.tangledhelix.com/projects/{{ project_name }}/
```
cards.name: Submit to Smooth Reading

cards.desc:
SR will hopefully have feedback for you. As it comes in, process it.

Send feedback to the SR. If you choose to ignore something they brought up, explain why you made that decision.
cards.name: Process SR feedback

cards.desc:
Run through the "HTML Finishing" list checks again before PPV.

Just in case.
cards.name: Final checks

cards.desc: Create a zip file to submit to PPV.
cards.name: Create zip file

cards.desc: Upload it to PPV. Finally!
cards.name: Upload

cards.desc: Update various points in the project with the final ebook link.
cards.name: Update project with links

cards.desc:
Now that the book is published, we probably don't need the space-consuming Pixelmator/Gimp formatted files anymore, especially if this project had a lot of illustrations.

Similarly, we don't need the ebooks or the zip archive; we can always regenerate those from the sources if we want to.
cards.name: Cleanup

checkItems.name: Add TN indicating errata were applied
Check if A.M. and P.M. had space in book, and if text matches that
If there's space, add   to ensure they don't break over line-end?
If you modified images (format), make sure IMG tags point to new name
Add an anchor for each illustration
Use the anchors instead of page number anchors, in the illustration TOC
Update project info card on this board
Search for `[Blank` and remove blank page markers.
Set due date on this card based on SR time period selected
Reassemble footnotes that are split into multiple pieces
Click `First Pass` to parse / tally up footnotes
Click `Check Footnotes` and address problems. Want all white (brown is OK if they're just long footnotes).
Determine if they can all just be renumbered globally. Check `All to Number` or `All to Letter`...
